comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: @AB - Need a higher res to examine those posters.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I'm on it....here you go! They are quite deteriorated, those posters.

AB

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Although not very clear, it is enough for me to make out at least the poster at right is an election poster for Will Daley, which would date the photo to c.1901 (but more likely 1902). 'Union is Strength' can be made out towards the top, and 'Will Daley' at the bottom, if you compare with one of the known election poster formats, using the zoom facility on this Powerhouse image - www.powerhousemuseum.com/collection/database/?irn=379076

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/] The first Bubblers weren't introduced to Sydney until 1914 - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/waterexhibition/DrinkingPlace... - The story of Sydney's Cast Iron Canopy Drinking Fountains, which were drinking cup fountains, can be found here -

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks for the larger size.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] - Good work! A fine distinction between bubbler and fountain.  That image link mentions a 1891 list of fountains including one at "Prince’s street, near Public School".  

I think it is most likely to be 1901.  There are many photos of Princes Street, almost every building, and several photos are marked 'Sept 1901'.  Hence the tatty Election Posters.  One photo is dated "11.9.01". 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2632254683/]

But there's a problem - the buildings don't match for the supposedly same stretch of street.  I can't yet prove it, but I think THIS photo is misnamed, and is from further north on Princes Street.  Work in progress . . .

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I agree, its from further north, but not much further. Those buildings in the photo you linked can be seen bunched together at left (imagine a square to the right of your Grosvenor note) - hard to make out because of the angle. Maybe a better description would be 'West side of Princes Street looking towards Little Essex Street and Essex Street beyond' ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Melbourne installed the same design. This one has morphed into a hybrid: a Cast Iron Canopy Bubbler! - www.picturevictoria.vic.gov.au/site/melbourne/NorthMelbou...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
A cast iron drinking fountain, so much more than just a bubbler! Thanks for the links. 

Based on the Will Daley poster I think we can date this one c.1901 as we have done with the others in our collection that [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] has spotted so far.

AB

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] The high res was brilliant and has really brought the photo to life. I'm now on the hunt for photos showing those listed drinking fountains ... the fun never stops in the interactive world that is State Records NSW on Flickr!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] NEWSFLASH: The date is in fact September 1901, just as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] suggested. This photo is a cropped version. The original photograph, dated September 1901 in that familiar capitalized script, is also in your collection - PRINCES ST. LOOKING SOUTH FROM NO. 69 SEPT.-01 [SRNSW: 4481_a026_000177]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Brilliant - the answer is often under our noses. "No.69" is about where Cribbs Lane would cross Princes Street (if it did) see map. About a 'block' north from Little Essex Street. I suggest using John Degotardi's title on this photo too. Was it Wednesday 11 September 1901, about 10am from the shadows?! I am still having a problem fitting this photo with the above - have we made a mistake? - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5516234724/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmm, you're right, it can't be from 95 Princes Street, otherwise we would be able to see buildings in the above streetscape. So, the question is, is the street or the number wrong? I think we should continue the discussion over on the photo - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5516234724/

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Mystery SOLVED! (or should I say confusion resolved?)

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: This photo was recently determined to be part of the Rocks Resumption photographic survey, the title and date of the image has been changed accordingly Here is a map of the Rocks Resumption area (last one in the sequence)
